This is SOOOOOO technically trivial, and yet so useful to anybody who really cares about getting a rock-solid non-blurred shot that it is a travesty for ANY digital camera not to have support for this kind of optional external accessory.  I mean it's like buying an expensive BMW and then looking down where the cigarette lighter should be and just seeing an empty hole.  Dumb.  Really dumb.More stuff I wish I could have...Connectors:  Now that these pockatable cameras are getting big zooms and other higher-end features, how about thinking outside of the box and providing just some cheap/easy but potentially extremely useful connectors, specifically (a) a good old fashioned flash "sync cord" socket and/or (b) a micro phone jack / TRS jack where an external stereo microphone could be plugged in?  Either of these would be technically trivial and dirt cheap to add, so how about it manufacturers?You manufacturers really don't have to worry about these extra features causing "cannibalization" of your higher-end (and more expensive) DSLR or super-zoom bridge camera lines for the simple reason that the markets for these things are just plain DIFFERENT MARKETS.  Anybody planning a trip deep into the amazon rain forest and who wants the best photos he can get IS going to buy a DSLR, no matter what nice little tweaks he can get on a pocket portable.  Conversely, anybody going into the jungle and who just wants some snapshots to take home is NOT going to spring for a DSLR or an expensive bridge camera... or be willing to carry the extra weight... just so he can get an external mic jack or an electronic shutter release.  Different markets.  'nuff said.Here endith the lesson.Other than the above nits, I actually love both the F300EXR and the ZS7.  They are both stunning and phenomenal pieces of engineering.  But of the two, the ZS7 is the one I will be keeping.P.S. One other small nit about digital cameras generally and the ZS7 and F300EXR specifically. All the digital cameras I've ever owned, including these two news ones are all apparently too stupid to even know which way is up.  Literally.  Can't you manufacturers fix this??  iPhones seem to always know which way is up, so why can't all digital cameras?(Like many of the comments above, the following comments are addressed to the camera manufacturers.)Look, this is very simple guys.  Every JPEG file has a built-in orientation and thus, a built in "upper left" corner.  So why is it that when I take my digital camera and orient it vertically, you know, as in "portrait" orientation versus "landscape" orientation, and then I take a shot and then load the JPEG onto my PeeCEE and then try and view the thing, the picture shows up on my screen lying on its side, rather than oriented properly?  This is definitely YOUR FAULT for not writing the JPEG file in way so that it will have proper (gravity based?) orientation.This is beyond stupid, particularly because I know for a fact that both the ZS7 and the F300EXR do in fact know which way is up, and they just aren't using that information properly.  I know they know which way is up, because in default factory settings on both, when I play back any JPEG that was shot "portrait" (vertical) it shows on the LCD in ``proper'' orientation, i.e. holding the camera normally (horizontal orientation) and then playing back a vertical-orientation shot, these cameras re-orient the images so that they appear on the LCDs vertically, and with big wide black bands on either side.  To accomplish this, obviously both cameras must be adding some sorts of annotations to all JPEGs they produce which indicate whether the shot was taken horizontally or vertically.  So the cameras do know which was is "up" for any given shot.  And they even save notes about that for each shot/JPEG.  Unfortunately, both cameras are too dumb to simply arrange for the JPEGs themselves to be oriented properly, based on which was is up and which way is down at the time the shot was taken.  That's dumb.  Really dumb.P.P.S.  Lowepro Ridge 30 cases fit either of the cameras described above perfectly.  DO NOT try to get a Ridge 20, based on the interior size specs and the exterior size specs for these cameras. First, you will have trouble finding a Ridge 20, because apparently, they don't make them anymore.  And as I learned, even if you get one, you will wish you hadn't, because they are so tight that it will be a chore getting either of these cameras in or out of the case.  Go with the Ridge 30, which is just slightly roomier, and thus perfect for either of these cameras.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera, once you take the time to learn it.
Reviews.Author: Computer Depot
Reviews.Content: I am amateur photographer who loves taking pictures wherever I am.After my Samsung ST45 died on me last year, I was in search of a replacement.I stumbled across the F300EXR while googling for camera deals.After reading the reviews I was very skeptical, about the purchase. However I was able to find the camera as an open box item for $149 with free shipping and figured it was worth the risk since there was nothing in that price range that could beat the specs on paper.I wanted a camera that was very portable, Wide Angled, High Zoom and durable.Here is my take after having for just over 2 months:Build Quality and Design Layout:The camera feels sturdy and is well built. My main concern is the paint coating. I have a case for the cam, but often slip it in my pocket or rest it on surfaces when stabilizing a shot. I now have some areas where little bits of paint have been scratched away. I thought this occurred way to easy for such a well built camera.Image Quality and Performance:To be honest my expectations probably where a too high, just like some of the other reviewers who gave negative comments on this cam. The hype from the product site suggested I was going to take DSLR type pics with this cam. Which truth betold I think I have. But that is in certain conditions, which is why I still am satisfied with the performance of this cam. I have taken pics that I never thought possible with such a compact and low priced camera. The camera indoor performance is not that impressive. But once you have good lighting; macro, portraits and landscape shots are wonderful. The GUI and Camera options allow for loads of adjustments before taking a shot. Those who have complained about getting poor shots, should visit the following site kimletkeman.blogspot.com loads of tips and sample shot of the F300EXR and the new F550EXR. The dynamic range feature also allows some effects and contrast to standout that you might miss with comparable cams. Write speeds could have been a little faster.Conclusion:I am happy with my F300EXR and plan to take a lot more great photos with it. I might consider the F550EXR if I can spare the money end of year as the GPS and enhanced noise reduction are appealing.I didn't bother to go into details about the Zoom, 12MP, flash and ISO as I am not a pro. I would suggest anyone who is considering buying this camera to just google F300EXR on flickr and make your decision from there.Have a look at my pics an let me know what you think.flickr.com/photos/askjasonbowen/5742169237/in/photostream

Reviews.Title: Next fuji of many
Reviews.Author: stuart
Reviews.Content: You can say that I'm a fuji fan, after owning a f40fd (sold), f100 (lost in a taxi) and a f200exr (still have, well my wife does anyway). They make good camera's.After trying the f300exr on a business trip, I have to say that I love ths little camera as well. The negative that people point out are valid to a certain extent, but this is a neat, tidy and very clever little camera - ideal for holiday work.Low light performance - not as good as my previous fuji's, but then it was never going to be, as the sensor is smaller, with a higher resolution, and a higer f number lense. It is however still OK, but not a great as it used to be.Flash - having the flash pop up every time, and it's location isn't ideal, as it gets in the way of my finger, but the neat little thing that nobody mentions, as that if you just push and hold it down, the camera automatically detects this and turns it off! This is so much better than having to go into the menu and cycle through the settings to try to do this. I therefore think that it's an improvement overall.Zoom - huge, love the rsnge, even if my grip isn't steady enough to hold it steadyFuntionality - loads of really nice gimmicks, that actually work, face recognition, panorama, EXR and dynamic range are great.Overall I am very happy with this camera, and it is idealfor my use - travel snaps and family photos. For low light party use, then I'll take my F200EXR instead.

Reviews.Title: I Love This Camera
Reviews.Author: Scott Bright "scottypotty"
Reviews.Content: I got the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS3 camera last year in December. This Fuji camera holds its own and surpasses that camera in some areas. It has a longer zoom, and more options. I really like the panoramic mode. I've taken some 360 degree shots that are pretty cool. I am very impressed with the Fuji brand and would definitely buy from them in the future. I recommend this camera and would buy it for a gift as well.Notes: - If you put it in your pocket without a case (to get it out of the way or something) the main dial tends to rotate and change the mode you are in.- When you are in preview mode, the picture loads in two steps. It comes up fast in low quality, then sharpens up as all the data is loaded.- There is no way to delete a picture right after you take it. You have to switch to preview mode, find it, and then delete it. I called customer support and they confirmed this. I like the delete function on other brands, but this isn't a big deal.- The flash pops up on the top left-hand corner of the camera. This is where I typically put my finger. I have had to get used to putting it on the side instead.- There are a ton of options and modes on this camera. Enough to let you play for a long time.- Very sturdy camera. Feels very well built.- The display screen is really nice. Your pictures will look amazing on it.

Reviews.Title: NOT a Simple Point-And-Shoot
Reviews.Author: G. Wingard
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera that fits my needs well.  I read a lot of reviews before buying this camera and, just as I felt before buying and using the camera, I found that most of the negative comments were from people who wanted the camera to be something that it is not.This camera has a Point-And-Shoot mode that is adequate if you are rushing to get a shot but if you know ahead of time what your shooting conditions are going to be then you can bet there is a setting that will get you great shots.  This camera is not for the novice photographer.  If you have experience then this camera has a lot of options to give you the control you need to get the results you want.

Reviews.Title: Maye I just got a terrible lemon, which raises quality issues
Reviews.Author: Carlooks "Carlooks"
Reviews.Content: My first use of this camera was so disappointing -- compared to other reviewers' and to Fuji F300 EXR tech specs -- that I did comparison shots with my tiny Canon SD780.  The tiny SD780 massively outperformed this Finepix EXR in every low-light shot.  Fuji's low-light performance was primitive at best. The Fuji's flash did not once fire properly over several evenings of testing. Fuji's pictures were very grainy (compared to the Canon SD780.) I tested and compared every plausible setting on the Fuji, very systematically. Fuji's focusing was slow, fuzzy and unreliable.  The Fuji EXR technology did not produce the background detail portrayed in the Fuji hype -- i.e., background was way overexposed so that all detail was totally burned out in a variety of scenery situations.  (I really wanted this feature to work too.) Only the Fuji's 15X zoom was better than the 3X zoom on my SD780. I'm outdoors lots, active and wanted small camera w/ big zoom to take along, rather than my larger camera with more zoom than my 3X SD780. I very sadly returned this Fuji Finepix camera, very disappointed that even my wishful thinking could not overcome the pitiful performance I got from this camera.  So until another mfr. offers a similar form/feature set, I'll rely on my Canon SD780 despite its measly 3X zoom -- it's really pocket size, it works great indoors/low-light, as well as in a wide range of outdoors/nature situations, the flash fires properly and the focus is relatively fast and very reliable.  I considered just exchanging this Finepix EXR but when a product that performs this poorly slips through Fuji quality control I'm just not willing to risk getting another lemon -- assuming the one I got was defective.  But maybe the Fuji F300 EXR I got was normal quality....

Reviews.Title: Blotchy, over-processed images, even at ISO 100/200 using flash. ISO 400/800 are useless.
Reviews.Author: Raj Reviews
Reviews.Content: I LOVED my Fujifilm FinePix F100fd.  I took EXCELLENT low-light images, even at ISO 400-800.  It had a 1/1.6" CCD sensor, the largest among point & shoot cameras.  Even my F40fd with a 1/.6" sensor took excellent low-light photos.When the F200EXR was released, also with a 1/1.6" sensor, and received good reviews on dpreview.com, it was on my list to buy.  But by the time I got around buying it, Photokina expo was just a few months away and I had a feeling that the F200EXR will be upgraded.  It did get upgraded with the F300EXR, but... the sensor was reduced in size to 1/2", the same size as most mediocre performing P/S cameras in low-light.Cautiously overexcited, and not wanting to wait for (if ever) dpreview.com's review of F300EXR's low-light performance, I jumped on Fuji's EXR-SN mode bandwagon, thinking that the EXR-SN mode will be so good, that it will compensate for the smaller 1/2" sensor.Boy, was I terribly wrong!  What a blunder I made.  Even though in dpreview's review of F200EXR they stated that the EXR-SN mode did not have much advantage over Lumix LX3's 1/1.62" sensor, I still foolishly believed that EXR-SN mode's pixel-binning (joining two adjacent pixels as one large pixel) would have a huge advantage.  It does not.At ISO 400, the images are so over processed, that they appear blotchy, having a water color effect.  The same could almost be said for ISO 200.ISO 800 is simply unusable.  A cell phone camera might take better photos.In spite of not having read a review of F300EXR on dpreview, and realizing that it had a much smaller 1/2" sensor (not good for low-light), the reason I bought this camera (and am returning it tomorrow morning), was because of its excellent specifications, and, these excellent sample photos taken by someone with the F300EXR (at ISO 200, Velvia mode, DR200):  [...]These above photos were proof enough for me that this must be an excellent camera.  Perhaps I got a lemon, but after extensive testing of my own at various modes and ISO 100 thru 800, in daylight and at night, with and without flash, I am convinced that even if I tested a replacement, I will get the same blotchy test results.  Even in daylight, when dynamic range is set to DR400, ISO 400 is used, and this in turn makes the photos blotchy.I had very high hopes for this camera, so much so, that I was recommending this camera to all my friends and relatives prior to my buying it, touting the EXR sensor, but also cautioning them that it had not been reviewed by dpreview, and that the sensor was too small.  I am soooo glad that they did not buy it (one almost did, but was not available at the store).The above sample photos, which convinced me to buy this camera, are still a mystery to me.I am returning mine in the morning, and will not be buying another P/S camera which has a sensor smaller than 1/1.6" or 1/1.7".

Reviews.Title: Good idea in a non-ergonomic body
Reviews.Author: Teapot Tales
Reviews.Content: Overall, this camera has great specs, but before you start using it, you have no idea how uncomfortable this little camera can be. First of all, it lacks any good grip curves and it is slippery (meanwhile, it is rather heavy for its size). Secondly, they designed this pop-up flash that is completely automatic and you cannot make it not to pop up every time you power camera up. And the spot where the flash pops up is where you really want to keep your left hand index finger.Even after you update this camera's firmware, the device still goes through batteries like crazy. One day of intermittent shooting could mean up to THREE battery changes.The video shooting mode has some atrocious auto-focus problems. The camera cannot keep up with any moving objects, so they keep being shot out of focus.Also, the wide-angle mode (no zoom) causes some pretty bad fish-eye like results, so if you have to shoot a portrait, you need to step back a little (if you can) and use a bit of zoom - like 2-3x.On the bright side, this camera has wonderful sensor mode settings, great low-light performance, it is rather fast and has tons of zoom power. While its small size can be a bit of disadvantage, but it does not change the fact that the camera is very portable and hardly takes up any space. It feels heavy and reasonably well-built.

Reviews.Title: Little powerhouse of a camera!
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Wilks
Reviews.Content: I received this camera yesterday.  Instructions read while the battery charged.  We had an event last night for our son, a cancer survivor, the American Cancer Societies "RELAY FOR LIFE" in Muskegon, MI.What an absolutely AWESOME event!  So I took the new Fuji F300EXR with us.  All I can say is this:* simple, sleek, ease of use, major zoom, photo effects are a huge plus!  The panoramic option is so cool!* I was able to do tons of stuff, easily, without having to look in the instruction manual.* Picture quality is fantastic!* Color is amazing!!*I'm thinking I found a new favorite!

Reviews.Title: great little camera
Reviews.Author: Marvin C. Latimer "Mel'sbells"
Reviews.Content: I saw the negative reviews of this camera and after reading a few of them it was obvious that they were either professional complainers or didn't read the manual to find out how the camera operated.  This is a really great little camera.  The thing that strikes you almost immediately is the clarity of the LCD display --- even in full sunlight it is clear..I don't see how you could take a "blurry or Fuzzy" shot with this camera.  I started out by taking a few shots in the house with the camera set to Auto.  In all but the darkest areas I got fine results.  I have a E-PL1 with a f1.7 lens that will do better, but this camera has only a 1/2" sensor and a f3.5 lens; I don't expect it to be perfect. Now I can carry this camera in my pocket and when I need a different focal length, other than the 40mm of my Olympus, I can pull this guy out and have a nice wide angle or telephoto shot, if one presents itself.I ran off about 100 shots around the house and then downloaded them and examined them on the computer.  I was very pleased with the results -- even when blown up to over 100% crop most of the shots were very acceptable.  8x10's will look great and 12x16's will even be possible. For the average person who just wants to take some shots on vacation or Easter dinner you can't do better for the money than this camera.One thing-----I didn't realize when I ordered this camera that Fuji now has the f500exr out.  It's about a hundred dollars more, but it has a back side illuminated sensor and 16 megapixels.  I'm sure it would be even better than this camera, but I'm satisfied with this one. I have two Canon elfhs and have had several Panasonic point and shoots.  Don't let any of these "fanboys" hawking one make or another deter you from buying this camera.  Most people would be very pleased with it and I doubt any of the really bad things said are true.

Reviews.Title: muddy images - get a lumix ZS7
Reviews.Author: al;
Reviews.Content: I was amazed to see how grainy and muddy the results of photos in good light were --the lumix ZS7 is about twice as goodthe on-screen menuing was clumsy and difficult to understand -- the panasonic beats itI thought the extra 3x zoom would make a difference -- but it seems that pushing a long zoom on either camera softens the resultthe extra 3x zoom is NOT worth anything in the endal;

Reviews.Title: Photonut
Reviews.Author: Edward Herkert
Reviews.Content: I have a Finepix S5200 that has taken many great pictures so I think Fuji makes a high quality product so when I saw the F300EXR's compact size, large LCD, 15x zoom I had to try it. I am not disappointed its great!!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera!
Reviews.Author: K. Johnson "FieryMaid"
Reviews.Content: I am not a picture person.  The last time I remember taking pictures was with film and a viewfinder.  After taking a picture, you'd have to wait weeks for them to develop and that's when you'd see how decent or awful your efforts were.  But I was taking a trip to Mexico City and I decided I had to do better than that.My sister had a two year old Sony cypershot she really loved, and I saw how easy it was for her to review and retake, load up pictures to her laptop and request prints online.  I knew digital was the way to go.  Instant notification of shot quality and only order prints of what you want.  I did weeks of online searching, learning aspects of digital cameras and professional and consumer reviews on how different ones held up.I settled on this one mainly for the features offered (especially the automatic modes and the incredible zoom) all in a very nice size.  As stated, I am not a photographer, so I wanted a few crutches to help me get amazing photos of my trip.  But I also like the option of being able to grow into something, and this has several features allowing manual settings.After two weeks of using this camera to photo the desserts and various ruins of Mexico as well as its beaches, I am proud to say this held up.  The zoom really is something else.  My father took his hefty digital SLR with telephoto lens and when we compared pictures, I couldn't see a difference, and I'd rather carry around this small camera than his huge one.I took the advice of several of the reviews I read and turned off the two facial modes.  I didn't think I needed them and I trusted it would improve battery life.  Whether or not it did, I can't be sure as I never tested the life with those modes activated, but I found the battery life lasted me all day and to spare.  I took indoor pictures with and without flash, outdoor with great lighting to low light, and night pictures.  I am very pleased with the results in all aspects.  In basically playing around with it, I discovered the best settings for different kinds of pictures.  Overall, I found the Auto mode seemed to have a richer color than the EXR pictures, so I would recommend just the Auto.Camera operation is very intuitive (I learn something new every time I use it), pictures are simple to upload, figuring out battery and memory cards insertion was a snap, the LCD screen is very visible in bright sunlight (even at full noon in Mexico), and the zoom is extremely quick and far reaching.  The only thing I have to complain about is already mentioned in other reviews:  the flash comes up any time the camera is on-even with flash mode turned off.  However it is very easy to get used to, and I did not find it to be a problem.As of writing this review, I haven't used the panorama 360 picture yet, or tried the fast shot mode, but if they are anything like the zoom or multi tracking, I'm sure I'll be very happy.I trusted Amazon enough to buy this "like new" from the warehouse, and I haven't had a single problem.  I am extremely happy with this purchase.  I think anyone new to digital photography would be pleased and I suspect even old pros would appreciate the capabilities of this small sized camera.

Reviews.Title: A non-photographer's review
Reviews.Author: L. Kornblum
Reviews.Content: I just want a small digital camera to capture memories easily, vacation spots, friends, family, special events. I'm not interested in composing a particularly artistic shot or spending time learning about the fine points of photography. I've been using a Panasonic Lumix DMC-FS15 12MP Digital Camera with 5x MEGA Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 inch LCD (Black) and have been mostly satisfied with it, but I was eager to try out and review this Fujifilm FinePix camera when given the chance.I was disappointed that there was no printed user manual included, just a "Basic Manual," which is a getting started type of guide. Instead, the enclosed CD contains a PDF file of the 144 page user manual. While I would have read, or at least skimmed, the entire printed manual, I am not fond of reading on my computer screen for very long. So I am on my own in figuring out the fine points of this camera, and will just use the PDF manual when I'm curious enough to look up a topic. This is annyoing enough for me to withhold a point in my rating.I've tried the camera out for a couple of days and am quite impressed with the quality of the pictures. They seem as sharp as those taken with my Lumix. So far I've found two features that raise the FinePix above the Lumix for me. It has a 15x optical zoom (compared to 5x on the Lumix), and it has a "motion panorama 360" setting that lets you take a 360 degree view of your surroundings by pressing the shutter and turning around quickly in a tight full circle. I've uploaded a customer image of such a shot which I took shortly after unpacking the camera and just playing around with the options. I was impressed with how easy it was to get this shot; so I am sure that as I explore more and read more there will be a lot more about this camera to wow me.Here are a few more observations:  Pro - the display monitor is bright and much easier to view in sunlight than that of the Lumix.  Con - the flash pops up exactly where I tend to place my left index finger while holding the camera, thus interfering with turning the camera on properly; I am concerned that this may damage the flash before I learn to keep my finger out of the way!  Con - with the flash set to "suppressed," it still lights up briefly as you press the shutter if the room is too dark

Reviews.Title: Makes an Amateur Look Pretty Good
Reviews.Author: K. Varraso
Reviews.Content: TRUE CONFESSION:  I am horrible at taking pictures.  My best picture of my mother looks as if she has a cherry tree growing out of her head.  Most of my other "treasures" have people without heads, trophies being handed to no one, and the soil in front of national monuments.In the past five years, I have reviewed my digital pictures and have found exactly none that were good enough to print.But all that has changed with the Fuji FinePix F300EXR Camera.  It has a nice, big LCD screen so I can tell if the picture I am about to take is not worthy of my efforts.  It keeps steady, so I don't get a smeared picture because I am not the steadiest of photographers.  The color and detail of my pictures was excellent, and none of my family members believed I took the photos.To me, that is the highest praise that I can give this camera.

Reviews.Title: Worst camera we've ever owned
Reviews.Author: D. Swenson "djs"
Reviews.Content: I typically have been loyal to Canon cameras, but a friend who owns a camera store talked my husband into this camera.  It's been the worst camera we've ever had.  It's not user friendly and the photos are almost always blurry.  Worse than a phone camera. You couldn't blow up any of these pictures at all.  I end up deleting more than I keep.  I would never buy another fuji.  I will return to Canon.

Reviews.Title: Good outdoors, horrible indoors
Reviews.Author: ManangK
Reviews.Content: I used to have a finepix f10 (and a much older before that which I used for 5 years and only replaced because it was old; was still working great and very sturdy). I used it a lot for taking photos for my food blog. It was great on close up with no flash. So after 2 years of using it (still working great and sturdy despite being subjected to flour and oil) I thought I'd "upgrade" to this one. Was I in for a major disappointment. None of the indoor photos were clear. All were blurry if I suppress the flash. If I use the flash, the subject or anything white is white...the darker subjects are dark...nothing is clear...I used different setting (EXR, Adv., etc.) but i have to say I am limited in my knowledge on cameras (just a p&s; type). Can't even use it on any family parties. Even the video (which I was hoping to use also to make yt vlog on cooking/baking) Outdoor pics were beautiful, though...but even my old cam does that. Since I blog regularly and have to use the camera almost daily, I just grabbed back my trusted old finepix f10 for any indoor photo and never changed its setting except for flash/no-flash and macro. I use this f300exr on family parties by the pool, or garden photos. I use another watertight/freezeproof/weatherproof fujifilm for underwater/beach type of family activity since it is also useless for indoor shots (I am a loyalist because of my experience with my first two finepix).I don't think I would trust any exr again. If anyone has another brand to recommend for my purpose, I would greatly appreciate it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Deb
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera through Murphy's Camera Shop and was very impressed with how quickly it arrived. They even sent the $50.00 rebate form. I sent the form in and received my check in a week..wow! Now for the camera..I purchased for a wedding gift for my son and his new wife. They had been to a camera shop and picked this camera out. They took it on their honeymoon to Colorado and said they love, love, love the camera. We watched the slideshow of all of their pictures, and the shots were amazing! They did not have anything negative to say about the camera. I tried the camera out before I gave it to them to make sure it was working for the honeymoon. The only small issue I had was with the location of the flash. It is in a spot where I normally have my hand, but I think it is something you can get used to. It is also a lot quicker than my digital camera. You do not have to wait between pictures. I would recommend this camera to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Atrocious picture quality - grain as if you're always shooting at ISO 3200+
Reviews.Author: scriptster "Scriptster"
Reviews.Content: It's a second Fujifilm digital camera I own and the first one (7M pixel) has been through hell and not only survived but  delivered consistently good results.This camera is a great disappointment though. The pictures are incredibly grainy, even in EXR-HR (Resolution Priority) mode, even with ISO manually at 100. The pictures look as if you took a normal JPEG file and saved it with 50% quality setting, no kidding here - at 100% zoom it's so bad the pictures are not usable.My uneducated guess is that this camera has software issues related to saving JPGs to the memory card. There might even be a firmware fix - I don't know but hope that this is it, and not a matrix-related issue. Otherwise I'm returning it.In any case, it sits well in the hand, it has great zoom and nice set of features but none of that is going to matter to you because you won't like the pictures that come out.

Reviews.Title: Great little point and shoot camera
Reviews.Author: skrishna
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a camera to carry around with me when I wasn't in the mood to lug around my Nikon D90 and all its lenses. My requirements were high picture quality and a long optical zoom in a reasonably compact case. I found all that and much more in the Fujifilm FinePiz F300EXR.Some key points:- The optical zoom is very, very impressive. I can't say enough good things about it.- The menus can be a little confusing - there are a lot of options. However, if you aren't in the mood to mess with settings, just taking with automatic settings results in fine picture quality.- I was really impressed by the low light/no flash quality of the images. If you shoot often without flash, or don't like the way flashes look, this camera is a great bet in a point and shoot.- The built in flash isn't great, unfortunately. It's weak; I've found it better to just turn the flash off.- It's sturdy - I've tossed this camera around, and had no problems with scratches, much less breakage.- The battery life is solid, but the LCD screen can be a bit of a battery drain, so it's best to turn the camera off when not using it.- Quick focus speed - you don't have to wait 10 seconds for the camera to focus!Bottom line: This is a great camera, and I'm very happy with it for a point and shoot. I highly recommend it if you're looking for a camera with a great zoom and image quality.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm Finepix F300EXR
Reviews.Author: Allan Hawkins V
Reviews.Content: Well people of Panasonic, this is better thans your, with the exception of that Pop-up Flash, why to ALWAYS pop-up??Saludos, Allan.

Reviews.Title: Inferior to F70
Reviews.Author: L. Zhang
Reviews.Content: I bought this F300 as a replacement to my F70 which I dropped to ground and broke last month. I was stunned when I saw the pictures on the computer. They were fuzy and nowhere as good as those from F70. I think it's because the F300 is a 12mp instead of 10mp. I adjusted ISO down to 200 and even 100, used P and A modes, but neither helped much. I returned the camera a week later and thought I should have bought another F70, if not a F200 which has 1/1.6 CCD instead of 1/2 CCD.

Reviews.Title: Can't beat versatility for the money...
Reviews.Author: R. Hendee
Reviews.Content: Quality build & performance.  Wide angle is terrific, zoom is amazing, 360 degree is cool.  As long as you understand what you're buying and your benchmark isn't a digital SLR, can't imagine you won't be pleased with this camera.  Truly an amazing little ultra-zoom point & shoot with incredible wide angle capabilities.

Reviews.Title: Feature Rich, Quality Poor
Reviews.Author: TechConsumer
Reviews.Content: I bought the camera in September and over time have noticed image quality degradation, now I am seeing spots (pixels) on the LDC and on photo's.  Clearly not a problem with LCD, but the sensor or what ever controls processing the image to the LCD and ultimately finished photo's.Of the three Fuji Digital Camera's I have owned, previously F200EXR and another F300EXR, it appears there are some manufacturing quality issues.  The first F300EXR I received was dead on arrival, I typically keep a camera for 3 - 5 years, unfortunately the Fuji's are falling short.While this camera has a lot of features that allow you to get very creative and adaptive to your situation, if falls short with low flash, short battery life, and noisy photos.  Fuji has always attempted to address my concerns by receiving the camera, repairing while under warranty, or offering to repair or upgrade once out of warranty; as you know, a lot of time is lost shipping, repairing and returning the camera.The flash is located on the top left of the camera, it gets in the way, leaving poor alternative to hold the camera.  The control wheel is at a very odd angle, a bit difficult to adjust until you adapt.Out door winter photo's are down right sad, the washout is unacceptable, low light photo's are good, but can be noisy.With some refinement the next generation will be better... I hope.

Reviews.Title: Only good for two years
Reviews.Author: Squire
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in June of 2011.  I really liked the quality of pictures.  You need to know that I do not let my camera sit on a shelf. I use it primarily in the outdoors so it gets its share of rough play and dust. About a year after the purchase, I noticed that the closing mechanism for the lens stuck  It seemed to remedy itself and all was well until a recent fishing trip when it would not work at ALL, and had the warning "! Lens Control Error" message on the screen.  I was in the far north Maine Woods w/o a camera!  And this was just two years after purchasing the camera.  Upon my return home I took it to the local camera dealer and he announced that he could not fix it and that it would cost $130 to return for repair! Checking online I found chats and blogs that indicated this was a problem with other users as well, and suggestions for owner repair ranged from banging the camera on a solid surface to using compressed air.  Nothing worked.  After returning home and learning that the cost of repair was ridiculous and that I would have to buy a new camera, I re-banged it on every side on a table and checked after each rap.  The final shock was on the lens face and be darned if that didn't remedy my problem, although probably temporarily.  It seems suspect to refuse to work again in the future. So, I have to wonder about this camera's long range reliability.  I won't be buying a Fuji the next time around.

Reviews.Title: My sister liked it so much she bought one for herself!
Reviews.Author: Sandy Kay
Reviews.Content: I'm not sure there is any better review to give than that I brought my camera over to my sister's house to show her and take some pictures and she liked it so much she bought one for herself. Her husband had given her a gift card to buy a camera from a big box electronics store but they didn't carry this camera so she ordered hers from Amazon rather than get a different camera with the gift card.I have a old school film SLR camera and used to be all about the settings but now I mostly just want to have a camera small enough to carry around and take pictures of family events.This camera has a lot of different settings you can use to take better pictures but the thing I like the most is that it takes really good pictures even with just the automatic setting.I'm really really happy with my camera.  I've had a Fuji point & shoot film camera and had an early Fuji digital camera and have always been happy with the Fuji quality.

Reviews.Title: Great for it's size
Reviews.Author: Business owner
Reviews.Content: Takes good pictures and easy to carry around when you want a smaller camera. Pictures are pretty good quality too

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: musicmt
Reviews.Content: We bought this a gift for our son (after doing extensive research) for part of his college graduation gift.  He then drove cross-country and captured the trip in pictures.  He loves the camera because it is compact and takes great pics.

Reviews.Title: BE careful.
Reviews.Author: A. Tay "Private Tay"
Reviews.Content: I know this camera is discontinuedBut the current versions are mainly vamped-up versions - with GPS, longer zoom, touch screenGOT this camera for an overseas tripLike all cameras, this one was built to perform under certain conditionsFor the best shots, you need to be outdoorsAt 24mm, it's f3.5At the 360mm setting, it's f5.3 - not that bad, since an average 300mm tele is f4Watch out because:a. even though the camera offers Aperture Priority and Manual, it offers limited f stopsSo at 24mm, it's f3.5, f7.1 and f11At 360mm, it's 5.3, 11 and 16Kind of disappointing if you like a bit more controlAmazing how camera makers always try this trickSome other camera maker offers just 2 f-stopsb. I was taking pictures of a cat and the f-stop went from f3.5 to 7.1Guess the aperture setting 'ring' is looseSo the shutter speed dropped a lotResult? Blur shotsc. the flash raises each time you power up the cameraIrritating in a way and worse, I think it lowers battery lifePlus side:The PASM ring is well builtEven though this camera is more than 2 years old, I prefer the design to the newer Lumix Tz25With the Fuji 300EXR,a. I don't need to switch between viewing and shooting(I suspect most people turn off the camera after viewing what they've shot)Most people won't slide the lever from 'preview' to 'shoot'So if you need to get a quick shot, chances are, you'll miss itBecause the camera was at preview and won't shootGets worse if you're the impatient sort like meI immediately zoom up when I turn the camera onAnd if it's in preview mode, it just means I've enlarged the picture I shot earlierThere seems to be a lapse when I switch from preview to shootCommon problems:a. When the makers increase the zoom, from say 15x to 24x, chances are, the maximum aperture at the widest setting also decreases, from around f3.0 to f3.5b. GPS shortens battery lifec. Touch screen doesn't work - that's just meTry to see how responsive it is with gloved fingers, greasy screen and wet surfaces

Reviews.Title: Battery life
Reviews.Author: G. mcpeak
Reviews.Content: Maybe I am doing something wrong but my battery gives up after only 6 hours and four or five pictures if the GPS tracking system is not manually turned off, at least that is why I think the battery has such a short life. apparently the GPS does not shut off when the camera is turned off.Took forever to figure out how to format and since it is one of the steps you must do to get the camera to work I wonder why they made it so hard to find?Camera maybe getting too small and as a consequence it is getting harder to operate than some of the older larger digital cameras.In my opinion the older larger digital cameras had a better feel to them.

Reviews.Title: Excellent choice
Reviews.Author: Guy
Reviews.Content: I did a lot research on this class of camera.This is by far the best choice for: battery life , ease of use, and picture quality.Buy a Sandisk 16 Mg ultra memory card, (the camera does not come with one) and you will have enough speed and memory for any outing or vacation.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix
Reviews.Author: LindaK
Reviews.Content: Tiny little camera with amazing results. Bought this for my husband, but now I want it. Haven't learned how to use all the features yet, but point-and-click is excellent. So is video. It's so much easier to slip this little camera in your pocket when you're on a trip. It gives even better results than my regular camera.

Reviews.Title: fufi F300exr
Reviews.Author: cad
Reviews.Content: This is a real nice camera and takes a great picture. The zoom is great and the automatic functions work well.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: oudpablo
Reviews.Content: This is my second Fujifilm digital camera. Previous one was an excellent fd40, unfortunately broken. I like this new camera very much. Metal case, sense and weight of a quality stuff. 15x zoom is awesome, put into such a small body. If you are not a "photo freak", EXR mode will do all for you in a simple way. The only think I really  don't like (along with many other customers)is the popping-up flash. Seems weak, and it's very annoying when trying to hold the camera. I hope to get the habit with time.That's the only one complain about this wonderful camera.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Richard
Reviews.Content: Love it! This camera is so light and easy to use. The zoom is great and I really like using this camera. It is small enough to fit into your pocket or purse. GREAT CAMERA!!!

Reviews.Title: I think I like it. . .jury is out
Reviews.Author: travelnwrite
Reviews.Content: I ordered this camera from Amazon after seeing it was $100 less from here than at my local camera stores.  What I gave up in the purchase was the ability to stop by and ask bone-head questions, but that will force me to read the 150-some page owners manual that comes on a disc in PDF format.(The cheapest batteries for it - and photo cards as well, have been here on Amazon, but watch the shipping charges, as they added another $15 to the postage-size purchase)I have therefore used it as simply 'a point and shoot' but know that its capabilities far exceed that and ultimately I hope to master them.I write a travel blog and freelance travel articles, so it is the perfect size to take along and produces the photos I need for both blog and print. It fits in purse or jacket pocket, although it is a bit heavy as it has metal components - which also makes it a bit more sturdy.I've not had the battery life problems that some have written about, but again I am using it on low resolution, auto, so may not be zapping its strength as I might when I start using other settings.The large LCD is good for boomer eyesight but honestly I do miss the eye view finder.  Holding a camera at arms length, twisting and turning, just doesn't seem an effective way to use a camera (especially when they sell little flexible tripods to steady it. . .the forehead did a nice job of that on the earlier models).The flash, as noted by others, pops up automatically and I haven't yet figured out how to override it, that skill, I hope comes in time.  The small users guide says, "Do not push back into the camera" so I must figure out how to get rid of it correctly.As I said the jury is out, but with some homework and practice I think this little travel companion will be a delight.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful!!!!
Reviews.Author: LB
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love this camera and would recommend it to anyone.  It is so easy to use and its features are great.  I wish I could post some of my pictures to show how close you can take a picture.

Reviews.Title: Very talented and flawed camera. Saved by the deal.
Reviews.Author: D. C. Fletcher
Reviews.Content: I've been using this camera for a few weeks now and can say I am very very please with it. I purchased it here for $199 shipped. Using it allot can say I certainly got my money's worth.Pros;All metal construction, extremely well built. On the flipside this will make me cry if I ever drop it far and it get scuffed. It is not flimsy at all though and feels far stronger than most Canon and Nikons.Zoom lens is great and works with movies.Compact and fits my hands well.Very fast auto focus and shutter. The hybrid phase/contrast AF seems to really work and this camera simply blasts out the shots compared to most.Very flexible PASM mode (Full manual controls)Excellent screen, only AMOLEDs on those Samsungs beat this.Wide angle lens. Corner blurring seems muted compared to reviews findings.$199, this blows anything else out of the water value wise.And Finally it has excellent Panorama modes!Now to the Cons:Noisy, this sensors is being pushed too hard. Zoom lenses let little light in compared to short lenses and this camera pays for it.You need to have a firm grasp of PASM mode to keep the aforementioned noise at bay.Battery can go fast and Like I said earlier I really really hope I don't ever drop it to hard.No way is this camera worth much more than $200. Even if it has the features the image quality is budget.

Reviews.Title: Fast shutter speed
Reviews.Author: PC User 58
Reviews.Content: It takes a little bit to get used to not putting a finger where the flash comes up. But I got used to it at the end.

Reviews.Title: Big performance, small package!
Reviews.Author: Mike Desotell
Reviews.Content: I am normally a DSLR man. I had been toying with the idea of getting a point and shoot to take with me "just in case" when I wasn't carrying my DSLR with me. When my wife (not a photographer)had the opportunity to travel to Israel a simple point and shoot became a necessity. Prior to the trip I put the camera through its paces and was impressed with its EXR features. In addition the HD video and the panoramic modes are great! My wife took over 2000 shots while in Israel and they were all pretty amazing. If I didn't know better I would have sworn she had taken my DSLR with her.The camera is also heavier than you would expect. Not so much that you can't hold it up and shoot all day long. Just solid enough that I don't feel like I am going to break it.The main problem I have with the camera is the same issue I have with any point and shoot I have ever used and that is the indoor and low light quality of the photos. This camera is better than most, but it still does not come close to what I would like to see for indoor shooting.The price is definitely right! You will not find another camera with these features and quality at that price. Fantastic job Fuji!

Reviews.Title: Camera failed after 30 days use
Reviews.Author: RAB "RAB"
Reviews.Content: The Fuji F300 is a ground-breaking, wonderful new design, takes good closeup images, and image quality at telephoto is excellent. Image quality at wide angle is not as good. But its continuous Panorama feature is the reason why I bought this camera. It's fabulous, but we took it on vacation and made wonderful pictures...until the panorama feature failed. Have sent the camera back to Fuji for repair. Am now wary of the reliability of this type of camera.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Hybrid
Reviews.Author: John Hollifield
Reviews.Content: Given the specs on the F300EXR, it's hard not the think of it as a hybrid camera--somewhere between your typical point-and-shoot and a quality DSLR.  The auto photos are good, but the best quality photos are a result of manipulation of the manual functions.  Either way, this is a very impressive unit for the price.  I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: For outside use only
Reviews.Author: sailorboy414
Reviews.Content: Got the camera from One Call. Fantastic customer service. I opened the camera used it and figured all was great. I had great expectations for this camera as I have a large Fuji camera that is really good and also had smaller one before that was excellent.On the nice LCD everything looked good until you looked closer. You could see some noise but I figured it was just on the small screen. Few days later I put the pics on my laptop. Absolutely everywhere were it was dark there was noise. Dark jackets looked like mosaic. As I was a competent photographer I figured that I could make this work, camera was very nice. I adjusted the settings as much as I could. I went to manual mode and limited the ISO to 200... still the noise was everywhere. Flash would light your face, but everything in the background was pixelated. EXR settings for low light bump up the ISO to 1600 making the picture full of noise. Outside the pictures were good, but in the end, I use my camera indoors a lot, so no good for me. I sent it back and will continue my search for a nice pocket zoom.

Reviews.Title: Good all around Point N Shoot Camera
Reviews.Author: K. Dubose
Reviews.Content: AAAAAHHHHH another point n shoot.  When I got chance to review the Fujifilm FinePix F300EXT point n shoot camera I jumped at the chance.  I currently have the Canon PowerShot G10, which I love but it's just too big for some occasions.  So I've been in the market for a smaller point n shoot camera.So I take this camera out of the box, first glance, I thought it's a handsome looking camera. Sleek and feels solid, which gives it a reassuring feeling when I held the camera.  So I switch on the camera and the blue light on the power key lights up. At the same time, the flash pops up from the body while the lens extends from the matte shell. The first thing I notice when you look at the top of the point-and-shoot is the mode dial, which is slanted toward the back of the camera. At first I thought it was weird but when I started using the camera, it's easier to access the ridged mode dial with our thumb compared with other point n shoots I've owned. There is a 3-inch LCD and a four-way clickable scroll wheel in the back of the camera.  The scroll wheel spins a little too loosey-gosey for so that forced me to slow down to get to the desired menu option. There is also a dedicated movie-recording button on the right side, though it can be hard to feel it with your thumb because it is flush with the camera's body.  After a little practice, you'll have not problem finding it without looking.Similar to other high-end FinePix models, the Fujifilm FinePix F300EXR offers five different film 'modes' to allow the photographer full creative expression to explore a variety of pre-set colour and contrast modes designed around Fujifilm's most famous film emulsions. The modes are: Velvia/Vivid (for dramatic full saturation colour), PROVIA/Standard (for classic 'neutral' photography), ASTIA/Soft (for gentle, low contrast portraiture and soft, fine, smooth tonality), Sepia (for antique, warms tones), and Black & White (for dramatic monotones). The FinePix F300EXR offers Program Mode, Aperture-Priority Mode, Shutter-Priority Mode and Manual modes to give the photographer creative control for those difficult or challenging subjects.The F300EXR gives a very impressive first impression and the actual images are pretty good.  All said and done though, the creative capability offered by a larger than average zoom in a smaller than average chassis cannot be underestimated. If you're prepared to put up with or work around its shortcomings, then the F300EXR is still well worth checking out.The bottom line: The F300EXR is recommended for those who want a compact camera with a long zoom lens and speedy focusing system. If your looking for a new digital camera to capture all of your precious memories then you probably won't go too far off the mark with the Fujifilm FinePix F300EXR. Extremely pocketable digital camera sports a high zoom range without taking up too much space, and yet is more than capable of delivering a slew of great looking shots under the ideal conditions.  Key word ideal conditions. For me it was a mixed bag, some pictures where good, others not so good. I used this camera in every possible condition bright, way too bright, dark, stills, action and everything in between.  With a little software editing most of the pictures came out great.  For me its pocket-friendly size, fits nicely in my hand for easy controlled shooting. The FinePix F300EXR is solid and finely crafted shooter, which is capable of standing up to minor knocks or abrasions. Apart from that, it also comes with a 3.0' high contrast (1:1200 ratio), wide-view LCD display that enables you to tilt the camera at different angles to see the picture. If I had to say a bad thing about this camera would be if your not shooting in ideal conditions, to really take excellent pictures you would have to manually adjust some of the camera settings. But with that said, you'll have to do that with any point-n-shoot. For the price, pretty good buy

Reviews.Title: camera
Reviews.Author: artist
Reviews.Content: excellent service  the new product in it's original package was sent in two days with an added bonus of a new camera case.This camera is small enough to fit in a pocket yet can zoom in 15 x without extra lens. Ideal for travel.

Reviews.Title: unclear pics
Reviews.Author: kater131
Reviews.Content: All of my pictures turned out very unclear and sorta blurry. I was very disappointed. I tried all different modes, and they all turned out cloudy. I suppose I could have been using it wrong, but regardless the pictures were very low quality.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing Camera
Reviews.Author: maRGARET PALMER
Reviews.Content: I'm very disappointed in this camera and would return if I could. Picture quality is very poor especially indoor pictures even with the flash. Focus, especially when using zoom, is incredibly slow and again poor picture quality (lots of noise).  Video again has lots of noise - not good.Camera design is poor; its hard to find a place to hold the camera with the awkward placement of the flash and as previously mentioned in other reviews the mode wheel moves too easily and changes modes without you even realizing it - have to check it before every picture.I bought this camera to take on a trip to Peru but quickly realized this wouldn't be adequate. Have since purchased a Nikon P7000- of course they're not even in the same  class so there's no comparison.

Reviews.Title: Just an average camera
Reviews.Author: Bim
Reviews.Content: From previous reviews I though it would be a good fit for me as an everyday camera that I could carry around and take some photos. But unfortunately, it is not a case with this one.Some cons that I discovered:Mode switch wheel - can be easily turned when you take out camera out of your bag and when you realize it, it could be too late for the shot/moment.Zoom - is not easy to get used to, it takes time to get adopted and it is not that smooth like in other cameras.In manual mode - aperture changing process is not good. Again - you have to adopt to it and always remember to check your aperture when changing zoom (focal distance).In panorama mode (ADV - advanced mode) - again - you have to learn how to correctly proceed with capturing image. Sometimes camera tells you that you moving too fast and sometimes too slow.Flash is not too powerful.Ergonomics of this camera were not well calculated. Need some additional work.

Reviews.Title: Not living up to expectations
Reviews.Author: Angie
Reviews.Content: I had the F200EXR until I broke it and LOVED it!  I should've just bought the same one again.  This camera is very very slow to turn on.  So slow that you think you didn't hit the button, well I found out (repeatedly) that if you hit it again it reformats the camera (not the SD card) back to the original factory settings. The picture quality I think isn't as great as the F200EXR.  The 15x zoom is good, except I'd recommend using a tripod or other stable platform or your pictures will be bad.  The 360 degree pictures don't turn out well either.  It's just a little too much.  I've used the Sony camera with the 180 degree pictures and they were amazing, so this camera left me disappointed in that area too. The pictures are too short in height and very long.  Depending on what you are shooting the pictures come out very disoriented. I wish I would have waited for more reviews of the camera before purchasing it and just gone with what I loved, the F200EXR.

Reviews.Title: I got the faulty camera
Reviews.Author: Huanqiong Lai "qiyuan guo"
Reviews.Content: I never owned fujifilm before,i refer the features,but when i received and turned it,and found it's a faulty camera,lends error,i didn't believe it,it was a new one!then contacted with fujifilm ,sent it to them and exchange a new,and take a month to process , waste my money and time!

Reviews.Title: Terrible photos
Reviews.Author: Scott Rhodes
Reviews.Content: I experimented for days with this camera and it simply does not take any good photos.  They look great on the little display but when blown up they have so much noise it is literally shocking.  It is hard to understand why the quality is so poor given the competition.  It does not matter how cool the gadgets are if the pictures are bad.  There is no way of knowing if it is the jpeg compressor because it is the only option.The worst thing is that I threw out the box so I can't return it.  A complete waste of money.  I wouldn't give it to my little kids because the would start crying that the pictures are so bad.
